items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely all day today, Wednesday 8 December and overnight tonight. Water levels continue to remain high. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 9 December.

High tides and strong winds are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire coast on the morning of Wednesday 08/12/2021 between 6am and midday. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous with debris. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Wednesday afternoon, 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to today's rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water.
Further rainfall is expected overnight and Derwent Water is forecast to remain high until Thursday.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Wednesday 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following the heavy rainfall this morning due to Storm Barra, river levels are continuing to steadily rise on the Rivers Clyst and Culm. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible this afternoon, Tuesday 07/12/2021 and overnight. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Wednesday morning, 08/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes.Â

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
There is no longer a threat of flooding at the present time, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with a moderate band of rain this evening, Wednesday 08/12/2021, however this is not expected to cause flooding impacts. The catchments remain wet and we continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 08/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. 
Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 2.5m to 2.7m morning of 09/12/21, Bredwardine 4.2m to 4.5m morning of 09/12/21, Belmont 4.3m to 4.5m afternoon of 09/12/21, Old Wye Bridge 3.9m to 4.1m afternoon of 09/12/21, Mordiford 4.1m to 4.4m afternoon of 09/12/21.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until 10/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 08/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until  10/12/21. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Onibury river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 09:00 Wednesday, 08/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:-   Onibury 1.7m to 1.9m Wednesday afternoon, 08/12.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 Wednesday, 08/12 or as this situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: The level of the River Yeo at Sherborne Lake remains marginally above Flood Alert threshold and is falling slowly. Other rivers in the area have fallen to winter baseflow levels. Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, with a moderate band of rain this evening, Wednesday 08/12/2021. While this is not expected to cause widespread flooding impacts, the catchments are wet and it may be enough to keep Sherborne Lake just above Alert level with a low level of flood risk in the local area. We will continue to monitor the weather and the Lake level over the coming days, and we will keep reviewing the need for this Alert. There may continue to be a localised risk of flooding to low lying land and roads in the area. We do not anticipate flooding of properties, based on the current forecast. Please remain vigilant and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow, Thursday 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Tuesday's tides at 11:00 AM  and 11:45 PM will be higher than normal due to stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour side and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
We are closing flood gates in the area.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 07/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

The high tide at  00:30 AM on Wednesday will be higher than normal due to stormy conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include The Quomps, Mudeford and the Stanpit area
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Wey as a result of rainfall during Storm Barra. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 08/12/21, especially in the Godalming area.  
Light rain showers are forecast for today, and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall which is forecast for tomorrow.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, 08/12/21.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: River levels remain high at the Great Bridgford river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today into tomorrow, Wednesday 08/12/2021. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook. Further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the Littlemead Brook/ Cranleigh Waters as a result of rainfall during Storm Barra.  Flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 08/12/2021.  Levels have fallen in the Ewhurst Road area, but have risen in the Flash Bridge area. Levels are now expected to fall.  
Light rain showers are  forecast for today, and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall which is forecast for tomorrow.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, 08/12/21.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk, and could respond quickly to even small amounts of rainfall, as the catchments are now saturated.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This Flood Alert may be removed later today (08/12/2021), if river levels continue to fall, but this will be based on an updated weather forecast this evening.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin overnight Tuesday, 07/12/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.7m to 3.9m  Wednesday evening, 08/12; Cae Howel 4.3m to 4.6m Thursday afternoon, 09/12.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen overnight as a result of heavy rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected from approximately 6am today, Wednesday 08 December 2021 at Kinnersley Manor, and is also possible along the River Mole as far as Cobham.  We expect flooding to affect land and roads.  Property flooding is not currently expected.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 5 days.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

River levels have risen on the River Douglas due to heavy rainfall. Areas at risk include The River Douglas from Horwich Star Vale to Appley Bridge including Adlington, Blackrod, Wigan, Standish, and Gathurst from 12:00 PM on 08/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon but the River Douglas is forecast to begin falling today (08/12/2021) and we do not expect any flooding to properties. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and do not walk or drive through flood water. items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton has been removed. The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area.

This Flood Alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from Storm Barra has now reduced. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The combination of spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences.  The first forecast high water is 21:00 on 07/12/21, with a level of 6.58 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:15 on 08/12/21, with a level of 6.19 mAOD and a Force 8 Westerly wind.
All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point, mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 
Flooding to coastal areas and the most vulnerable properties is possible tonight and tomorrow morning and may occur one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Strong winds are forecast again for Wednesday evening and this flood alert may remain in force for the high tide at 21:45.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the forecast high water is 21:30am on 07/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.40 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 9 in a westerley direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham, and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehamption Park, including Pill and Shirehampton, however conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.
Our operation teams are closing flood gates in the Pill and Shirehampton area. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

This flood alert has been removed. There is no longer a risk of flooding 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
The tide yesterday evening, Tuesday 8th December, at Newport reached 6.86m at 9:30pm and at Avonmouth reached 7.68m at 9:45pm.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at Braystones Beach at 2:00pm on 08/12/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides, this may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast.
Properties on the foreshore at Braystones, Nethertown and Coulderton are at risk.
Forecasts do not currently indicate that we will be issuing further alerts or warnings following this lunchtime's tide.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

The Flood Alert for this area has now been removed. 
Coastal conditions should ease for the tides over the coming days. 
We continue to monitor the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 14:15 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 5.09 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Littlehampton. After Thursday morningâs tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 14:15 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 5.09 metres Chart Datum (2.35 mAOD) at Littlehampton. After Thursday morningâs tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

Wednesday afternoon's tide at 14:15 on 08/12/2021 may cause flooding, as the shingle beach has been affected by storm Barra. Winds are Gale Force 8 Westerly. Waves remain large, but not as large as Tuesday afternoon. Adjusting for the weather, the total tide is forecast to be 5.45 metres Chart Datum (2.40 mAOD) at Littlehampton, nearly a metre lower than Tuesday. For 2 hours either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping beach. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Conditions are forecast to remain similar - generating similar minor impacts, until Friday, when winds should ease and wave heights reduce. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 08/12/2021.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 13:45 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 4.44 metres Chart Datum (1.70 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. After Thursday morningâs tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Irish Sea from New Brighton to Hoylake
items.message:
Flooding is possible. Areas at risk include land at the head of the Wirral from Hoylake to New Brighton and including parts of Leasowe and Wallasey.    
Wednesday afternoonâs tide at 1:15 PM is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with north-westerly force 5 to 7 winds and large waves.
Strong winds and spring tides may cause  waves and spray overtopping on the coast from between 1:15 PM and 2:15 PM.
Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, waves and spray overtopping on the coast.
There are no further high tides forecast. 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary.  
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated tomorrow, 9/12/2021, or as the situation changes

A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the first forecast high water is 21:30 on 07/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.40 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 9 in a westerly direction. The time and date of the second forecast high water is 09:45 on 08/12/2021. The forecast tide level is 6.95 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 8 in a westerly direction. 
There is a possibility of flooding for the Severn estuary at Severn Beach, including New Passage and Pilning. Conditions may apply one/two hours either side of the high tide.
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. Winds are forecast to be West South Westerly Force 7, gusting to gale Force 8 at times. Time of high water at locations along the East Dorset Coast is as follows: Weymouth Preston Beach at 21:00 and 09:15, Swanage Bay at 22:55 and 09:55, Poole Harbour at Wareham at 01:00 and 13:15, and Christchurch Harbour at 00:30 and 12:45. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Stay away from exposed beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 15:00 on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Storm Barra is forecast to bring strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping at the coast on Wednesday morning, especially at West Bay, Lyme Regis and Chiswell. Winds are forecast to be West South Westerly Force 7, gusting to gale Force 8 at times. Time of high water at locations along the West Dorset Coast is at 09:20 Wednesday 08/12/2021. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Stay away from exposed beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Avoid walking close to cliffs due to the high risk of rock falls in the prevailing conditions. This message will be updated by 13:00 on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
The high tide at 00:30 AM on Wednesday will be higher than normal due to conditions associated with Storm Barra. 
South-westerly force 8 winds and large waves will produce a swell within the harbour.
Areas most at risk include Wareham Quayside and Hamworthy.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive or walk through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

The tide level is now reducing and it is no longer expected to cause property flooding. The tide forecast in the early hours of Wednesday morning (08/12/2021) at 01:45 remains a little elevated, with larger waves. As there is a small possibility that some very minor impact flooding may occur, a Flood Alert will remain in force for this tide. The Flood Alert will be issued shortly.
The tide level is now reducing. The tide forecast in the early hours of Wednesday morning (08/12/2021) at 01:45 remains a little elevated, but it is no longer expected to cause property flooding.

As there is a small possibility that some very minor impact flooding may occur, a Flood Alert will remain in force for this tide. The Flood Alert will be issued shortly.

This Flood Alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from Storm Barra has now reduced. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

We will continue to monitor the situation. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Wednesday afternoon are forecast to be lower than that experienced Tuesday afternoon by almost one metre. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 14:00 Wednesday afternoon 8/12/2021 will be 6.23 metres Chart Datum (2.71 mAOD) at Newhaven. After Thursday morningâs tide, each subsequent tide through the next week will be lower again. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon, seafront properties
items.message:
The Flood Warning for this area has now been removed. 
Coastal conditions should ease for the tides over the coming days. Please note, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  
We continue to monitor the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

Storm Barra has broughtÂ  strong, Force 7, south westerly winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
High water will be at about 10:00 pm this evening, Tuesday 07/12/2021.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the weather conditions.
Areas most at risk include The Sea Life Centre and the Preston Beach Road area of Lodmoor.
Our incident response staff are in the area and will be checking local defences.
Plan driving routes to avoid Preston Beach Road which may be affected by flooding.
Stay away from Weymouth beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021.

Storm Barra has broughtÂ  strong, Force 7, south westerly winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
High water will be at about 10:00 pm this evening, Tuesday 07/12/2021, although levels will remain high for several hours afterwards.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the weather conditions.
Areas most at risk include the inner harbour, East Beach and the esplanade on East Beach.
Our incident response staff are in the area and will be checking local defences.
Avoid going near cliffs as the risk of cliff falls is considerably raised during storm conditions.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will remove this message by 10:00 AM on 08/12/2021.

River levels all along the River Uck have now returned to near normal, following the heavy rain brought by Storm Barra on Tuesday. The weather forecast suggests Wednesday, Friday and the weekend should remain largely dry in Sussex. However, a band of rain will move across the country Thursday afternoon 9/12/2021. The predicted amount of rain Thursday is currently 7-15mm, which shouldnât cause significant flooding problems, but river levels will rise again. Possibly to a similar height measured Tuesday, and therefore the risk of minor flooding could return. Please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again Thursday. You may like to keep flood protection measures in place, or close by. We will re-issue this message if we have increased confidence in the risk of flooding to properties

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
Further light rainfall is forecast for tonight, Wednesday 8th December 2021 but we do not expect this to cause any further impacts.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels remain high following heavy rainfall from storm Barra. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today, Wednesday 8th December 2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Great Stour and the River East Stour, particularly in and around Ashford and around Stone Cross. 
Further light rainfall is forecast tonight Wednesday 8th December 2021.  
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated this evening, Wednesday 8th December 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of Storm Barra. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 5am and 8pm today, Wednesday 8th December 2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the river, particularly in the Staplehurst area.   
Further light rainfall is forecast for tonight, Wednesday 8th December 2021.  We expect river levels to remain high until 8pm on Wednesday 8th December 2021.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated  this evening, Wednesday 8th December 2021, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 5am and 8pm today Wednesday 8th December 2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Medway particularly footpaths and riverside areas in the Maidstone area and particularly around Aylesford. 
Further light rainfall is forecast for tonight, Wednesday 8th December 2021.  We expect river levels to remain high until 8pm on Wednesday 8th December 2021.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  this evening, Wednesday 8th December 2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen as a result of yesterday's rainfall at Stapleford. Consequently, flooding is possible along the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.
   
Further light rainfall is forecast today meaning river levels are likely to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated this evening, 08/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hookagate river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between today, 08/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Church Stretton. Other locations that may be affected include Minsterley, Pontesford and Harrington. The floodplain has started to fill adjacent to the gauge on the left bank.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 08/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Byton river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin this afternoon, 08/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads to the River Lugg north of Leominster. Locations that may be affected include Yarpole, Mortimers Cross, Kingsland and the B4362.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until 16:00 on 08/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning 09/12/21 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.
